entry.title: Configuring Multi-Time-Zone Support in SAP SuccessFactors (Single Time Zone Currently Set)
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

I was wondering how to configure the time zone settings for an SAP SuccessFactors instance that is currently set to a single time zone, and add support for multiple time zones.

As far as I understand, there’s no additional setup required—each user can simply select their time zone in Job Information. Is that correct? If there are any additional settings I need to configure, could you please let me know?

- The tenant preferred time zone is set to Asia/Tokyo, and we plan to add additional countries such as the United States, China, the United Kingdom, France, and Mexico.

Thanks in advance.

entry.title: SAP Cloud ERP (S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition) 2602亮点前瞻—销售话题
entry.content:
本文章将覆盖以下主题内容：

  1. APP: 管理销售凭证
  2. 高级销售首付款申请
  3. 高级公司间销售-销售套件
  4. 组条件阶梯价应用
  5. 销售流程扩展性
  6. 销售凭证打印：输出渠道EXTOM
  7. 新增API配置点
  8. 开票偏离过账日期
  9. 经典公司间开票应付账款后台处理框架
  10. 客户退货无需退款流程 

1. APP: 管理销售凭证 

业务需求

作为销售代表通过APP:管理销售凭证来完成日常工作任务，可以根据相关筛选条件轻松过滤销售凭证抬头、项目或计划行信息。筛选结果以列表形式显示，便于进行后续操作处理。可以对凭证进行批处理任务，比如批量更改价格，检查信用等。支持快速跳转到相关APP。

系统实现

APP：管理销售凭证，实现直接查看销售订单抬头，项目和计划行信息

批量更新价格和检查信用

总体状态快速浏览

2. 高级销售首付款申请

业务需求

标准首付款业务场景BKJ在结算时会有舍入差异的问题，公有云2602版本升级后通过高级首付款场景可以解决此痛点需求。

详细系统实现链接：销售高级首付款申请 - SAP Community

3. 高级公司间销售-销售套件

启用销售套件与高级公司间销售功能，使销售公司能够向客户销售销售套件，同时由关联公司负责履行交付。

注意：销售公司向外部客户销售由库存物料和非库存物料组成的销售套件，而交付公司负责履行交付。对于通过采购订单订购的库存物料，始终执行公司间开票（关联公司之间）。

  • Sales sits ERLA – 价格，库存，物流交付在主项目

  • Sales kits CPFH -价格在主项目, 库存和物料交付在子项目

  • Sales kits LUMF - 价格，库存，物流交付在子项目

  • Sales kits DISH – 价格在子项目, 库存和物流执行在主项目

销售订单LUMF案例：

4. 组条件阶梯价应用

前提配置

SSCUI：Set Pricing Procedure (101117)

SSCUI: Set Condition Types for Pricing in Sales (101120)

系统实现

创建价格条件记录ZIQG，产品TG11：

创建价格条件记录ZIQG，产品TG12：

创建销售订单，TG11数量2，TG12数量3，组条件数量5

查看销售订单TG11价格，取的是组数量5的阶梯价：

查看销售订单TG12价格，取的是组数量5的阶梯价：

5. 销售流程扩展性：自定义字段从产品主数据到销售订单行项目扩展

业务需求

客户需要自定义字段从产品主数据衍生到销售订单行项目，目前客户需要自定义数据表来链接相关关联，2602版本更新了此功能，这减少了客户工作处理时间。

系统实现

1. APP：自定义字段，参考以下业务场景

2. 产品主数据

3. 销售订单行项目

6. 销售凭证打印：输出渠道EXTOM

业务需求

新的输出渠道EXTOM可以在销售凭证中使用，这个渠道可以发送数据在XML格式中到外部系统。如果客户使用除Adobe Document Services外的工具来生成打印表单，那么这个渠道就特别有用。

前提配置

在使用新的渠道EXTOM前，客户需要激活并且配置业务场景7DJ(Integration of External Output Management Solution)，需要在OPD(Output Parameter Determination)中增加新的渠道EXTOM。

7. 新增API配置点

业务需求

对于销售订单，客户可以定义在销售合同项的自动分配出现问题时，特定的 API 如何做出反应。

您还可以定义当 OData V4 API 对模拟销售订单的创建或更新操作遇到错误时，该 API 应如何响应。

配置点

1. SSCUI：107106, 为销售订单中项目的自动分配问题定义API反应

2. SSCUI: 107246, 设置销售凭证模拟 API 的错误处理模式 (OData V4）

8. 开票偏离过账日期

业务需求

考虑一个常见场景：咨询顾问每周五进项项目服务过账时间确认，但实际开票在次月5日进行。当其中某个周五落入新的过账期间时，合理的做法是使用上月最后一天作为过账日期，但将开票日期设为次月5日。这种设置确保成本（时间确认）和收入（开票金额）都能分配到同一个过账期间。 此外，如果开票后出现争议，可以保留原始发票的开票日期，同时将过账日期调整到当前期间，从而避免开票期间和过账期间不匹配的问题。

系统实现

9. 经典公司间开票应付账款后台处理框架

当交货公司将公司间发票应收账款过账时，输出处理会自动触发相应应付账款到销售公司账户的过账。从销售公司的角度来看，这些应付账款代表交付给客户的货物的供应商发票。为了使此过账机制按预期运行，需要执行特定的设置步骤。

系统目前提供两种方法将代表公司间发票的应付账款过账到销售公司的账户。这两种方法都在公司间发票的输出处理期间触发：

  • 方法1（推荐解决方案）：通过后台处理框架（bgPF），使用输出通道EDI 如果您是首次设置应付账款的自动过账，请使用此方法。

    详细过程请参考：Automatic Posting of Payables to the Selling Company’s Accounts | SAP Help Portal

  • 方法2（即将废弃解决方案）：通过IDoc处理，使用输出通道IDOC 在以前的版本中，这是标准解决方案，但现在不再推荐使用。

10. 客户退货无需退款

业务需求

客户退回第三方供应商提供的免费样品，无需向客户退款，直接退回供应商。

2602版本更新前：

  • 使用后续物流活动0005或0007时，系统强制要求提供退款，即使实际不需要退款
  • 必须先创建退款凭证，然后再拒绝这些退款凭证来完成退款状态
  • 导致系统中产生大量不必要的退款凭证

2602版本更新后：

  • 可以精确控制退款决策，无需创建不必要的退款凭证
  • 确保客户退货的凭证流转清晰、简洁
  • 直接支持无退款的供应商退货流程

感谢观看

entry.title: Instalando a API da Calculadora da Reforma Tributária no BTP
entry.content:
Em julho de 2025 a Receita Federal liberou a primeira versão da ferramenta oficial para cálculo da reforma tributária sobre o consumo. Antes dessa data, o uso era restrito às empresas participantes do programa piloto.

O primeiro recurso é a calculadora online, que recebe os dados da operação e retorna os tributos calculados em tela. Esta calculadora pode ser acessada pelo seguinte link: https://piloto-cbs.tributos.gov.br/servico/calculadora-consumo/calculadora/regime-geral

Porém, o recurso mais importante é a chamada "Calculadora Offline" que permite a instalação local e sobretudo a integração com qualquer ERP por meio de uma API.

Esta API foi desenvolvida em Java e Springboot e o download pode ser feito pelo seguinte link: https://consumo.tributos.gov.br/servico/calcular-tributos-consumo/calculadora/calculadora-offline

A calculadora offline possui versões para Windows e Linux via Docker, mas eu quero mostrar aqui como subir esta API no BTP, tornando ela visível ao seu ERP ou Middleware (PI, PO, CPI, etc.)

O primeiro passo é baixar a versão Docker no botão "Baixar Programa". Será baixado um arquivo ZIP de aproximadamente 260MB.

Ao descompactar o arquivo o único que nos interessa é o "calculadora.tar.gz"

 

Agora você vai precisar de uma conta docker (https://www.docker.com) e baixar o Docker Desktop para o sistema operacional de sua preferência.

 

A partir deste ponto vamos usar o terminal do seu sistema operacional:

Use o comando "docker login" para iniciar a sessão.

docker login

 

Em seguida vamos utilizar o comando "docker save" para criar uma imagem com base no arquivo baixado do site da Receita Federal.

docker save [nome da sua imagem] > calculadora.tar.gz

O próximo passo é carregar a imagem com o código-fonte por meio do comando "docker load":

docker load < calculadora.tar.gz

Na sequência vamos criar uma tag "1.0" para o nosso novo repositório por meio do comando "docker tag":

docker tag [sua imagem]:latest [nome de usuário docker]/[seu repositório]:[sua tag]

 

Agora vamos usar o comando "docker push" para fazer o upload do nosso componente para o repositório Docker Hub. Aguarde o final do upload.

docker push fapurcino/calculadora-image:1.0

 

Agora vamos fazer o deploy para o BTP via linha de comando. Primeiro você vai precisar do utilitário CLI, que pode ser baixado gratuitamente em https://docs.cloudfoundry.org/cf-cli/install-go-cli.html

 

Para fazer login no BTP via linha de comando basta digitar "cf login", informar o endpoint e suas credenciais do BTP. Após o login, serão listadas todas as subaccounts que você tem acesso e você precisará escolher qual delas receberá a API.

cf login

 

 

Para garantir a compatibilidade do Java, crie um arquivo chamado manifest.yml na mesma pasta do arquivo calculadora.tar.gz com o seguinte conteúdo:

applications:
- name: calculadora-image
  memory: 1G
  docker:
    image: fapurcino/calculadora-image:1.0
  timeout: 180
  env:
    JBP_CONFIG_OPEN_JDK_JRE: '{ jre: { version: 21.+ } }'
  command: /opt/java/openjdk/bin/java -jar calculadora/api-regime-geral.jar --spring.profiles.active=offline --spring.datasource.url=jdbc:sqlite:calculadora/calculadora/db/calculadora-pro.db

 

Com o terminal na mesma pasta digite o comando:

cf push [nome da sua aplicação] --docker-image [seu nome de usuário docker]/[seu repositório]:[sua tag]

 

 

Após a conclusão do processo deve aparecer uma linha "running" indicando sucesso. Note que existe uma rota criada em "routes". Esta rota pode ser acessada pelo BTP pelo navegador de sua preferência.

 

Veja que ao adicionar o segmento "/api" na URL você terá acesso à documentação padrão swagger e poderá fazer todas as chamadas desejadas à API.

https://[rota gerada para sua subaccount]/api

Ou conforme exemplo:

https://calculadora.cfapps.br10.hana.ondemand.com/api

Espero que este post tenha sido útil. Curta e compartilhe com outras pessoas que podem achar isso útil em seus projetos.

 

Um grande abraço

Fabio Purcino

entry.title: CI/CD & SCTM Setup on SAP BTP (NestJS + React Extensions)
entry.content:
In my previous post, I focused on developer productivity and measurable outcomes. This time, I’m switching gears to delivery engineering: how we build and ship two independent apps—a NestJS backend and a React frontend (behind Managed AppRouter)—as extensions on SAP BTP Cloud Foundry, using SAP Continuous Integration and Delivery (CI/CD) and SAP Cloud Transport Management (SCTM).

SAP CI/CD gives us predefined CI/CD pipelines we can configure and run as jobs. 

SCTM adds controlled transport, an import queue, and manual approvals when needed. 

 

What We Deliver (Two Apps, Two Lifecycles)

1) React Frontend (behind Managed AppRouter)

We package the React UI so it’s served through SAP BTP Managed Application Router, meaning we don’t maintain our own AppRouter runtime. 

2) NestJS Backend

Standard Node.js service deployed to Cloud Foundry, independently released from the frontend.

 

The CI/CD Flow (End-to-End)

  1. Merge happens into a tracked branch (we use test and master).

  2. Bitbucket webhook triggers a CI/CD job.

  3. CI/CD runs a Cloud Foundry pipeline and builds an MTA from mta.yaml.

  4. In the Release stage, the job uploads the built artifact to a SCTM node.

  5. SCTM puts the transport into the import queue, where we manually forward/import if the node is configured for manual control. 

 

SAP BTP CI/CD service with jobs definition example.

 

SAP BTP Cloud Transport Management service with transport node detail.

 

Our Branch & Job Strategy (Simple and Explicit)

We keep it intentionally “boring”:

  • React repo
    • Job for test
    • Job for master
  • NestJS repo
    • Job for test
    • Job for master

This avoids “one job that behaves differently depending on branch logic” and makes it obvious what ships from where.

 

Our SCTM Strategy (Auditability Over Minimal Clicks)

To improve auditability and clarity for customers, we use separate SCTM nodes per environment and per domain:

  • TEST-FE, TEST-BE

  • PROD-FE, PROD-BE

That’s four upload nodes for two environments.

Why we do it:

  • Cleaner history (“frontend vs backend” separation without filtering gymnastics)

  • Easier review and approval flows when different people own FE/BE releases

What it costs:

  • More nodes = more configuration + more manual imports

SCTM supports manual control via Import Queue when the node’s forward mode is Manual. 

SCTM Node configuration detail.

 

SAP CI/CD Setup (What We Configure)

1) Credentials

We create three kinds of credentials:

  • Bitbucket access (clone/pull)

  • Webhook credentials (to trigger builds from merges/pushes)

  • SCTM service key credentials (for “Upload to” in release)

CI/CD is designed around configuring jobs that run predefined pipelines. 

 

Credentials definition section in SAP BTP CI/CD service.

 

2) Repositories + Webhooks

For each repo in CI/CD:

  • Add repository (Bitbucket Cloud)

  • Attach credentials

  • Configure webhook so merges trigger the job

 

Repositories integration section in SAP BTP CI/CD service.

 

3) Jobs

For each branch job:

  • Select repository + branch

  • Build tool: MTA

  • Build descriptor: mta.yaml (repo root)

  • Optional: lint, unit tests, scans (pre-transport quality gates)

 

Jobs definition section in SAP BTP CI/CD service.

 

In Release:

  • Release type: SCTM

  • Operation: Upload to

  • Node: one of TEST-FE/TEST-BE/PROD-FE/PROD-BE

 

Basic definition of a job including Cloud Transport Management service integration.

 

SCTM Destinations (Deploying to the Right CF Org/Space)

SCTM uses destinations to address deployment targets for MTA deployment on Cloud Foundry. 

If you use OAuth2Password authentication via SAP Cloud Deployment service, SAP notes two critical details:

  • Client ID must be cf

  • Token Service URL must point to Cloud Foundry UAA 

 

Example of a destination configuration needed for SCTM service.

 

What’s Shared vs. App-Specific

Shared Practices (React + NestJS)

These rules apply to both repos:

  1. mta.yaml lives in the repository root (so CI/CD can reliably find it).

  2. package.json and package-lock.json are in the root.

  3. Dependencies install via npm ci for reproducibility.

  4. Build step is always explicit (no hidden magic).

  5. Only artifacts that passed CI checks get uploaded to SCTM.

 

React App (Managed AppRouter): Minimal MTA Wrapper

Our typical structure:

  • /approuter (Managed AppRouter module/config)

  • /ui (React app)

  • /mta.yaml (root)

  • /package.json (root)

Managed AppRouter is intended to run HTML5 apps without maintaining your own runtime. 

Build logic (conceptually):

  • npm ci

  • npm run build

  • post-step: ensure a manifest.json is present for packaging requirements (even if the React runtime doesn’t “use” it)

Important configuration files:

  • mta.yaml
_schema-version: "3.2"
ID: mta_application_fe
version: 0.0.1
modules:
- name: mta_application_fe-approuter
  type: approuter.nodejs
  path: mta_application_fe-approuter
  requires:
  - name: mta_application_fe_html_repo_runtime
  - name: mta_application_fe-destination-service
    group: destinations
    properties:
      forwardAuthToken: false
      name: ui5
      url: https://ui5.sap.com
  parameters:
    disk-quota: 256M
    memory: 256M
- name: mta_application_fe_ui_deployer
  type: com.sap.application.content
  path: .
  requires:
  - name: mta_application_fe_html_repo_host
    parameters:
      content-target: true
  build-parameters:
    build-result: resources
    requires:
    - artifacts:
      - uionboarding.zip
      name: uionboarding
      target-path: resources/
- name: uiapplication
  type: html5
  path: ui_application
  build-parameters:
    build-result: dist
    builder: custom
    commands:
    - npm ci --include=dev
    - npm run build
    - ./ensure-manifest.sh
    - sh -c 'cd dist && jar cfM uiapplication.zip .'
    supported-platforms: []
resources:
- name: mta_application_fe_html_repo_runtime
  type: org.cloudfoundry.managed-service
  parameters:
    service: html5-apps-repo
    service-plan: app-runtime
- name: mta_application_fe_html_repo_host
  type: org.cloudfoundry.managed-service
  parameters:
    service: html5-apps-repo
    service-plan: app-host

parameters:
  deploy_mode: html5-repo
  enable-parallel-deployments: true
  • package.json
{
  "name": "application-fe",
  "version": "0.0.1",
  "description": "Build and deployment scripts",
  "scripts": {
    "clean": "rimraf resources mta_archives mta-op*",
    "build": "rimraf resources mta_archives && npm run prepare-ui && mbt build --mtar archive",
    "prepare-ui": "mkdir -p resources && cd ui_application && npm install && npm run build && ./ensure-manifest.sh && cd .. && npm run create-ui-zip",
    "create-ui-zip": "cd ui_application/dist && mkdir -p ../../resources && zip -r ../../resources/uiapplication.zip . && cd ../..",
    "deploy": "cf deploy mta_archives/archive.mtar --retries 1",
    "undeploy": "cf undeploy mta_application_fe --delete-services --delete-service-keys --delete-service-brokers"
  },
  "devDependencies": {
    "mbt": "^1.2.29",
    "rimraf": "^5.0.5"
  }
}
  • ensure-manifest.sh
#!/bin/bash
# Make sure manifest.json exists in the right place
if [ -f "dist/manifest.json" ]; then
  echo "manifest.json already exists in the dist folder"
else
  echo "Copying manifest.json to dist folder"
  cp public/manifest.json dist/
fi
# make sure that xs-app.js exists in the right place
if [ -f "dist/xs-app.json" ]; then
  echo "xs-app.json already exists in the dist folder"
else
  echo "Copying xs-app.json to dist folder"
  cp public/xs-app.json dist/
fi

 

NestJS App: Minimal MTA for a CF Node Service

Structure is standard NestJS:

  • /src

  • /test

  • /package.json (root)

  • /mta.yaml (root)

Build logic (conceptually):

  • npm ci

  • npm run build (which runs nest build)

This “thin MTA descriptor” is enough to let SAP CI/CD build it through the standard MTA path and hand off to SCTM.

Important configuration files:

  • mta.yaml
ID: application-be
_schema-version: '3.3'
version: 1.0.0

modules:
  - name: application-be
    type: nodejs
    path: .
    parameters:
      buildpack: nodejs_buildpack
      memory: 512M
      disk-quota: 1024M
      command: npm run start
    build-parameters:
      builder: custom
      commands:
        - npm ci
        - npm run build
      ignore: ["node_modules/", "test/", "e2e/", "coverage/", ".vscode/"]

    requires:
      - name: malware-scanner
      - name: postgresql-db
      - name: connectivity-service
      - name: destination-service
...
  • package.json
{
    "name": "zapka-parents-be",
    "version": "0.0.1",
    "description": "",
    "author": "",
    "private": true,
    "license": "UNLICENSED",
    "scripts": {
        ...
        "build": "npm install && nest build",
        ...
    },
    "dependencies": {
        ...
    },
}

 

 

General Outcomes: Why This Setup Works for Us

  1. Predictable builds

    Same entry points (mta.yaml, npm ci, explicit build scripts) across both stacks.

  2. Clear audit trail

    CI/CD builds, SCTM transports; SCTM import queue enables controlled promotion. 

  3. Better separation of concerns

    Dev teams focus on code + CI quality gates; deployment approvals happen in SCTM when needed.

 

Conclusion: Control Without Killing Automation

This setup gives us a stable delivery backbone:

  • CI/CD handles automation and repeatability.

  • SCTM provides governance and auditability via nodes and import queues.

Yes, extra nodes create extra manual confirmations—but for customer-facing enterprise delivery, the clarity is often worth it.

 

Questions for Discussion (How Do You Do It?)

  1. Do you use one SCTM node per environment, or do you split nodes by domain (frontend/backend) for auditability?

  2. Do you chain nodes strictly (DEV → TEST → PROD), or allow direct uploads to higher environments?

  3. Where do you enforce manual gates—only before PROD, or also between lower environments?

  4. If you split FE/BE: how do you keep transport naming and history readable over time?

  5. What’s your preferred balance between fewer nodes (less ops effort) vs more nodes (cleaner audit trails)?

entry.title: Re: Extreme performance problems with new application for...
entry.content:
Can you explain this "after some confusing hacks to get it to work"?

What kind of hacks did you do, coding or dependencies or ????

Is this a WEB or Desktop APP?

If I recall the old native Delphi component was a wrapper around the code crpe32.dll engine, that was deprecated back in CR 10.

Lots of old posts on performance using .NET, due to the nature of .NET Framework, lots of resources having to be loaded.

So your noted delays are actually typical.

There are a few ways to work around some of them...

1. Preload a dummy report so it loads all of the dependencies, use dummy reports with the printer define under Page Setup.

1.a. Do not use No Printer, design the report using a real printer:

1.b. Always use Dissociate, this way the Engine will try to find a match if the Design Printer is not found.

1.c. NEVER use Microsoft's EasyPrint, it's inProc print driver, CR has always required a real printer driver when designing reports.

If Server based you MUST install the actual printer being used, same if local PC printing.

If the printer saved in the Report is not found, CR will search for it, which is why you must use Dissociate, so it stops looking for the original.

May explain your noted 1 and 2.

There is a sample VS .NET app for printing, not sure if Delphi can load it, but it explains a lot of How To's when using No Printer, uses a dummy report to load the defaults:

Printing Crystal Reports in .NET

Also note when No Printer is used then USP10 and some of the PC's Default printer properties are used to format the page. Using a real printer then GDIPlus.dll is used to format the page.

Hope that helps....

entry.title: Re: Consuming SAC export API into Excel ODATA feed
entry.content:
@Manvendra_Singh26 

The export url for Dimension Master Data can be augmented with parameters to directly export to a CSV format. The response can be generated in .CSV format using the $format=text/csv parameter in the request. Something like below.

https://<TENANT_URL>/api/v1/dataexport/providers/sac/<PROVIDER_ID>/<DIMENSION_NAME>?$format=csv

This will download the CSV directly and you do not have to use Power Query ODATA connection.

 

Hope this helps !

Nikhil

entry.title: Intelligent Alert Management in SAP Cloud ALM with SAP Build Process Automation
entry.content:
If you ever wonder how to configure custom email notifications for SAP Cloud ALM events or whether notifications were sent to the right team, you’re in the right place. I’d also like to cover SAP Build Process Automation’s fairly new generative AI capabilities and how they can help us configure automations, processes, forms, and rules within BPA.

I’ll guide you through the process using the Certificate Expiry event in SAP Cloud ALM, but the same approach can be applied to other event types as well. In SAP Cloud ALM, certificate expirations are rated as either Warning or Critical, depending on how you’ve configured the thresholds. By default, SAP Cloud ALM may send an email using a template like the following:

SAP Cloud ALM for Operations
Expired Certificate – CF Cloud Integration Tech P&P Int
Alert Context: CF Cloud Integration Tech P&P Int
Reported At: 2025-12-03 12:08:57 UTC
Priority: High
Status: In Process

As you can see the default email does not include:
    1, Which certificate (CN/alias/subject) is expired
    2, Expiry date and “days overdue / days remaining”
    3, Where used (endpoint / integration artifact / runtime)

You may want to enrich the message and send a customized email to the right team.

Let’s see how we can achieve this...

Context

1, Configure an event in SAP Cloud ALM for the desired monitoring application. In this example, we use Health Monitoring for Integration Suite (Cloud Integration).

2, When we configure an event in SAP Cloud ALM, we can enable alerts and add Operations Automation as an action. If an alert is open, we can start the operation flow manually by clicking Actions. If the event is triggered, the operation automation starts automatically.

3, Once the operation flow is triggered, we can view the execution logs in SAP Build Process Automation under the Monitoring > Processes tab, including the context payload sent from SAP Cloud ALM to BPA.

 

Configuring the workflow:

1, Create a process automation in SAP Build Process Automation

2, If generative AI is enabled in Control Tower, you should see the Generate button.

3, First, create a process using the generative AI functionality. For example:
“Generate a process called ‘customAlert’ with a decision table and an email step.”
This will create a basic process skeleton:

4, Next, add the process inputs that BPA expects from SAP Cloud ALM (refer: Operation Flow | SAP Help Portal). For an operation automation, you typically receive values such as:

  • automationId
  • timestamp
  • eventDetailsTable (This will be an object, include the certificate details we wish to call…)
  • serviceName       etc..

You must define these as process inputs in BPA—and you can use generative AI for this as well. For example:

‘Create process inputs for rating, timestamp, serviceName, eventName and lmsRole’

5, Then, add an API trigger.

6, Create a Script Task before the decision table to parse the eventDetailsTable from the payload and either use "rating" from the payload or derive a custom severity (CRITICAL/WARNING) based on the "days until expiry" value. Tiny snippet:

var t = safeParseJson($.context.startEvent.eventDetailsTable);
var rows = (t && Array.isArray(t.rows)) ? t.rows : [];
var overall = "WARNING";

for (var i = 0; i < rows.length; i++) {
var days = parseFloat(rows[i][4]); // Value = days until expiry
if (!isNaN(days) && days <= 7) { overall = "CRITICAL"; break; }
}

$.context.custom.certseverityoverall = overall;

7, Configure a Decision Step for correct email routing:

Click Open Editor. This step determines the notification recipients based on the incoming values and the rules you define..

For example, a CRITICAL severity in PROD should be routed to the on-call team. In contrast, a WARNING severity in DEV can typically be routed to the standard support team.

In the Decision step, define the required inputs and outputs for this routing logic. Add rating and systemType as input parameters, and recipient as the output parameter.

Now, create a rule using generative AI, for example:

‘If the rating is CRITICAL, then recipient must be support@oncall.com’

8, Open the Mail Body Editor as the final step and reference the variables in your custom email.

9, Deploy and Verify:

Deploy the workflow in SAP Build Process Automation, then register it in SAP Cloud ALM via the Operations Automation tab.

Assign it to the “Expired Certificate” event in Health Monitoring for Integration Suite (Cloud Integration). When the event is triggered, the operation flow will start automatically and send the appropriate email to the appropriate team.

entry.title: Creating and Accessing an IAS Tenant on SAP BTP (Part 2)
entry.content:
In Part 1 of this series, the role of SAP Cloud Identity Services – Identity Authentication (IAS) as a foundational component for enterprise-grade SAP Decentralized Identity Verification (DIV) implementations was introduced.

This article focuses on creating and accessing an IAS tenant on SAP BTP.
At this stage, no DIV-specific configuration is performed. Instead, the identity foundation required for later integration with DIV is prepared.

 

Positioning in the Overall Architecture

At a high level, IAS acts as a central authentication and authorization layer between corporate identity providers and DIV components.

This architectural positioning corresponds to the enterprise requirements introduced in Part 1, where IAS acts as the central identity layer between corporate identity providers and DIV (Figure 1).

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Figure 1: High-level identity architecture integrating SAP Cloud Identity Services (IAS) with SAP Decentralized Identity Verification (DIV).

 

Prerequisites

Before starting the setup, the following prerequisites must be fulfilled:

  • An SAP BTP global account
  • A BTP subaccount (existing or newly created)
  • Administrative permissions to:
    • Manage entitlements
    • Create service instances
    • Configure identity services

 

Step 1: Access the SAP BTP Global Account

  1. Open the SAP BTP Cockpit: https://account.hana.ondemand.com/#/home/welcome
  2. Log in using SAP credentials
  3. Select the relevant global account
Note:
In enterprise environments, multiple global accounts may exist (for example, development, test, and production). The correct global account for the DIV implementation must be selected.

 

Step 2: Select or Create a Subaccount

Subaccounts provide logical isolation for different projects, environments, or organizational units.

  1. In the left navigation panel, open Account Explorer
  2. Either:
    • Select an existing subaccount, or
    • Create a new subaccount:
      1. Click Create → Subaccount
      2. Enter a display name (e.g. manufacturer-div-test)
      3. Select a region (e.g. AWS, Europe)
      4. Click Create

 

Step 3: Check and Add Cloud Identity Service Entitlements

IAS is provided as part of SAP Cloud Identity Services and must be entitled before it can be consumed within a subaccount.

  1. In the subaccount, navigate to Entitlements 
  2. Search for Cloud Identity Services
  3. If the service is already listed, continue with the next step
  4. If the service is not listed:
    1. Click Edit in the top right corner
    2. Select Add Service Plans (top right)
    3. Search for Cloud Identity Services
    4. Select the service
    5. Choose the default application plan
    6. Click Add Service Plan
    7. Click Save

Good to know:
Each SAP BTP global account includes one free production IAS tenant and one free test IAS tenant.

 

Step 4: Create an IAS Instance

The IAS instance represents the actual IAS tenant that will later serve as the identity provider for DIV.

  1. In the subaccount navigation, go to Services → Instances and Subscriptions
  2.  Click Create
  3. Configure the instance with the following values:
    • Service: Cloud identity Service
    • Plan: default
    • Runtime environment: Cloud Foundry
    • Instance name: for example, manufacturer-div-ias-test
  4. Click Create

Provisioning of the IAS tenant typically completes within 1-2 minutes.

 

Step 5: Access the IAS Admin Console

After provisioning is complete, the IAS administration interface becomes available.

  1. In Instances and Subscriptions, locate the newly created IAS instance
  2. Click on the instance name to open the instance details
  3. Open the Admin Console or Dashboard URL (URL format: https://<tenant-id>.accounts.ondemand.com/admin)
  4. Log in using SAP credentials

The IAS Admin Console is the central place for:

  • Managing users and groups
  • Configuring authentication and identity federation
  • Controlling access to DIV wallets and provisioning tenants

 

Result

After completing the steps above:

  • An IAS tenant is successfully provisioned on SAP BTP
  • The IAS Admin Console is accessible
  • No integration with DIV has been configured yet

This completes the identity foundation required for the DIV setup.

 

Read more

➡️   Continue with Connecting IAS with SAP Decentralized Identity Verification (Part 3)

⬅️   Go back to Why IAS Is Essential for Enterprise DIV Implementations (Part 1)

 

  • Introduction to SAP Decentralized Identity Verification (DIV) and Related SSI Blog Posts 
  • Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI): A Usage Catalyst for Data Spaces 
  • Feature Scope Description for Decentralized Identity Verification (help page)
  • What Are Cloud Identity Services? (help page)

entry.title: Ariba CIG : Service PO mapping not working
entry.content:
Hi Team,

We are facing one issue when trying to do mapping for a Service PO. Where the Quantity & Price value flip happens for both the Service & Material PO. Below is the requirement

Requirement:

If the PReq Item is a service (i.e. Service Start Date <> blank), then map the:

  • PR Qty field -> PO Price field
  • PR Price field -> PO Qty field

Keep PR UoM field mapped to PO UoM field

Note: We have Item Category = 'M' only as per client requirement.

Based on the above requirement we tried mapping in “PurchaseOrderExportRequest”. However, we are facing some challenges in our test environment where the desired output is not achievable.

  • Steps Performed: PR Qty field -> PO Price field

1) Mapped Quantity (PurchOrdScheduleDetails_Item) to NET_PRICE(PO_ITEMS)

  •  
  • 2) Added Source condition to the Custom Date (Custom Section)

     

  • 3) Created PR5373. Has 2-line items:

1st Line item has a Commodity code as 'Service' , Service Start & End Date are not blank & Item Category = 'M'. - Here the value flip is successful

Payload: 1st Lineitem

2nd Line item has a Commodity code as 'Equipment' ,Service Start & End Date are Blank , Item Category = 'M'. - Here also the value flip happens which should not happen.

Payload 2nd line item:

 

I believe it is because of looping Custom field takes consideration of the field text(ServiceStartDate) alone in the mapping without considering if it has got a value or not.

So, we would like to understand how we can overcome this situation where we need only Quantity & Price should flip when the “ServiceStartDate” <> Blank. ?

If I add a new Custom Field for Service PO as “Service Flag” in the same Custom section.

Question:  Will the new Custom field will have the same impact just like the above mapping where the mapping will not consider whether the field is Blank / not Blank when present in the Custom section?

entry.title: How We Built a Smart Data Scrambling Solution for SAP SuccessFactors HCM Using SAP BTP
entry.content:
Introduction

In most organizations, HR data is constantly used in non-production systems—whether for testing, development, training, or troubleshooting. During my work with SAP SuccessFactors landscapes, I’ve often seen how these environments are created quickly by copying data from Production—simply because it’s convenient and readily available.

The problem is that these environments often contain real employee data. This includes names, dates of birth, national IDs, salary details, phone numbers, and home addresses. From my experience, this is where serious privacy risks begin. Even a small oversight can lead to compliance issues under data protection regulations.

At the same time, simply replacing all values with dummy data does not work. Testing requires realistic data. Reporting hierarchies must remain intact. Validations must still pass. Payroll and downstream integrations must continue to work. I’ve personally faced scenarios where masked data looked safe—but broke workflows, reports, or approval processes.

So the real requirement is not just masking—it is smart anonymization that keeps the data functional while removing all sensitive information. This realization is what led to the idea of building a more intelligent, rule-driven, and enterprise-ready data scrambling solution.

Our Approach

To address this challenge, we built a Data Scrambling Solution for SAP SuccessFactors HCM on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) using the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP).

While designing this solution, one of my key goals was to ensure that it feels native to SAP environments—secure, scalable, and easy to integrate. Instead of simply overwriting data with meaningless dummy values, the solution intelligently anonymizes employee-related information using randomized and pattern-based substitutes.

What really mattered to me during development was realism. I wanted test and sandbox systems to behave exactly like production—so validations still pass, workflows still function, and integrations remain intact—while ensuring that no real personal data is exposed.

With this approach, organizations can confidently use non-production systems for testing, training, and demos without compromising data privacy, regulatory compliance, or system integrity.

Key Features and Benefits

1. Comprehensive Data Scrambling

  • The solution scrambles all sensitive HR fields, including employee names, dates of birth, national IDs, phone numbers, email addresses, home addresses, compensation-related information, and more.
  • What makes this approach different is that it preserves referential integrity across key SuccessFactors entities such as Employee Profile, Job Information, Employment Details, and Position data. Relationships between employees, managers, and organizational structures remain intact even after scrambling.
  • As a result, the output remains realistic and fully usable for functional testing, regression testing, and integration testing, ensuring that business processes continue to behave as expected.

2. Configurable Scrambling Rules

  • The solution allows users to define scrambling rules directly from the application at entity level.
  • It supports multiple anonymization techniques, including Randomization, Pattern-based masking, Substitution lists, Pseudonymization
  • These rules are highly flexible and can be tailored to meet specific project requirements, regional regulations, or internal compliance policies.
  • The configuration framework is also designed to support future enhancements, allowing new entities and rule types to be added easily without redesigning the solution.

3. Flexible Execution Options

The solution provides flexible execution modes to suit different project and compliance needs. Users can choose to:

  1. Run full scrambling across the entire dataset
  2. Perform partial scrambling based on Employee groups, Countries, and Selected modules

A simulation mode is also available, allowing users to preview scrambled values before applying them. This helps validate the rules and avoid unintended changes. This selective execution capability ensures that scrambling can be tailored precisely to the required scope without impacting unnecessary data.

4. Realistic and Functional Output

A key design principle of the solution is to ensure that the scrambled data remains fully functional. All transformed values are generated in valid, system-compatible formats, including:

  • Valid date formats
  • Properly structured email addresses and phone numbers
  • Preserved manager–employee hierarchy
  • Country-specific and locale-aware formatting

As a result, business processes, workflows, validations, and integrations continue to function normally—just without exposing any real personal information.

5. Download Scrambled Data

  • The solution provides a secure option to download scrambled data as exportable files for further analysis and audit purposes.
  • Users can easily export anonymized datasets along with summary logs in standard formats such as CSV and Excel.
  • These downloadable reports make it simple to perform data validation, compliance checks, and quality reviews, ensuring transparency and traceability of the scrambling process.

6. Email Notifications

Once a scrambling job is completed, the system automatically sends an email notification to the user. The notification includes:

  • Access to the scrambled output
  • Processing summary
  • Job completion status

This ensures timely communication and eliminates the need for manual follow-ups or repeated system checks. Users can conveniently access the finalized scrambled dataset directly from their email.

7. Secure SAP SuccessFactors Integration

The solution integrates securely with SAP SuccessFactors using:

  • OAuth-secured OData APIs, 
  • SAP Destination Service, and
  • SAP BTP runtime

All data extraction, scrambling, and updates are performed securely within SAP Business Technology Platform.

Architecture and Technical Stack

The Data Scrambling Solution for SAP SuccessFactors is deployed on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP) and follows a secure, cloud-native architecture.

Users access the application through SAP Build Work Zone, which acts as the central entry point. The App Router loads the user interface from the HTML5 App Repository and handles authentication using SAP Identity Authentication Service (IAS) or a federated identity provider.

Once authenticated, all requests are routed securely to the backend using SAP Destination Service.The backend is built using the SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP). It contains the complete scrambling logic and communicates with SAP SuccessFactors through trusted OData APIs.

To ensure traceability and audit readiness, all activities—such as job execution, errors, and processing details—are logged using SAP Application Logging Service.

This architecture ensures:

  • Secure data flow
  • Proper authorization
  • Controlled access
  • Full auditability

Solution Flow

  1. User launches the Data Scrambling application from SAP Build Work Zone
  2. Frontend UI (SAPUI5) is loaded via the App Router
  3. User authentication happens through SAP IAS
  4. Requests are forwarded to the CAP backend using SAP Destination Service
  5. Backend fetches data from SAP SuccessFactors via OData APIs
  6. Scrambling rules are applied to sensitive fields
  7. Logs and audit details are recorded
  8. Final scrambled output is generated and shared

Business Value

  • This solution delivers strong business value by addressing both compliance and operational challenges.
  • It protects employee privacy by ensuring that real personal data is never exposed in test, development, or training environments. This significantly reduces the risk of data leaks and regulatory violations.
  • At the same time, it keeps test environments realistic and fully functional. By preserving data formats, relationships, and system behavior, teams can continue to test workflows, reports, and integrations without disruption.
  • The solution also reduces manual effort by automating the entire anonymization process. There is no longer a need for custom scripts, ad-hoc masking, or manual cleanup activities.
  • By eliminating manual handling of sensitive data, it lowers the risk of human errors that often occur during data copying or cleansing.
  • Finally, the solution is designed to be secure and scalable, making it suitable for both small teams and large enterprise landscapes.

Conclusion

Using real HR data in non-production systems introduces serious privacy and compliance risks. At the same time, relying on unrealistic dummy data makes testing ineffective and unreliable.

This Data Scrambling Solution for SAP SuccessFactors HCM bridges that gap by providing a secure, realistic, and automated way to anonymize sensitive employee information. By preserving data structures, formats, and relationships, the solution enables teams to confidently test, train, and troubleshoot without exposing real personal data.

From my own experience working with SuccessFactors integrations and test environments, I’ve seen how much time and risk this approach can save. Instead of manually cleaning data or writing one-off scripts, teams can now rely on a standardized, scalable, and auditable solution.

Ultimately, this is not just about compliance—it’s about enabling innovation safely. When teams no longer have to worry about data privacy risks, they can focus on building, improving, and delivering better solutions with confidence.

entry.title: Monitoring Event Mesh from SAP Integration Suite with SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:
We are taking one step further with event driven architecture in, now we can monitor event mesh metrics with SAP Cloud ALM.

One thing quickly may come into your mind that we have monitoring option in SAP Integration Suite, then what’s new with SAP Cloud ALM.

So below are main points where we need SAP Cloud ALM for monitoring Event mesh:

  1. The broker health can be monitored directly through the Broker State card.
  2. Customers can view the historical metrics data based on housekeeping settings in Cloud ALM.
  3. We are sending warning (80%) and critical (95%) alerts for these metrics, which are also configurable by customers.
  4. The biggest advantage of SAP Cloud ALM health monitoring is that customers don’t need to access the EMIS (Event Mesh in SAP Integration Suite) monitoring screen. They can simply add our service to their SAP Cloud ALM dashboard along with other services and monitor everything in one unified view.
  5. Big Picture of multiple event mesh services.

Now we will look in more details to understand above points,

Before monitoring the system let’s first understand that we need to add system/service (of SAP Integration Suite) into SAP Cloud ALM tenant for monitoring:

If you are customer, then you need to specify your customer id

And with this option, automatically at backed SAP will pull all connected tenants with their included services.

  • Open landscape management app from SAP Cloud ALM tenant. And check your customer ID.


Note: If you encounter problems connecting your managed services or systems to SAP Cloud ALM, please report a case(opens in new tab) using the following components:

  • SV-CLM-INF-CON – Connectivity of managed services/systems to SAP Cloud ALM
  • SV-CLM-INF-LMS – Landscape Management Service

Please select your SAP Cloud ALM tenant when reporting the case.

 

Activate event mesh monitoring in SAP Cloud ALM

Below are steps to activate monitoring:

  • Open the scope selector of health monitoring app.
  • Select your SAP Integration Suite (Event Mesh) service from the scope selector and apply the selection.

     

  • The SAP Integration Suite (Event Mesh) service will be displayed in the configuration section.
  • Enable the toggle button next to the service name to activate the data collection.

 

 

Monitoring metrics of event mesh

1. Metrics overview:

Component: Broker Statistics

Metrics:

  • Message Consumers - The number of active consumers receiving messages from the broker.

Threshold can be configured as per requirements. Example, here if message consumers value is 80% of 600 then status is warning and if it is 95% of 600 then critical.

  • Active Connections - Shows the number of active system connections to the broker.
  • Broker State - Shows the readiness of the broker.
  • Message Queues - Number of message queues defined in the broker.

2.  Alert

By selecting event mesh service from configuration option, events can be activated.

With this blog, you must have understood how to monitor event mesh service of SAP Integration Suite with SAP Cloud ALM.

 

 


If you want to understand about end-to-end monitoring of integration scenarios of cloud integration, then please follow this  blog 
If you want to check Cloud integration monitoring with SAP Cloud ALM, please follow this Blog

entry.title: More insights, faster resolution: Expanding Base Memory for SAP Cloud ALM
entry.content:
Why this change matters

Customers today are monitoring more systems and services, more integrations, and more user journeys than ever before. With advanced capabilities such as Real User Monitoring, Business Process Monitoring, Business Process Monitoring, Integration Monitoring, and AI-supported analysis, data volumes naturally grow—and that data is essential to deliver meaningful insights. For example, in Real User Monitoring, change point detection relies on continuously calculated statistical baselines derived from the preceding two weeks.

 

What’s changing

To better support modern monitoring scenarios and larger landscapes, we are increasing the base and extension memory from 8 GB to 24 GB.

  • Base HANA memory is increased from 8 GB to 24 GB
    – Applies to both, base tenants and tenant extensions
  • Base Outbound API monthly data transfer is increased from 8 GB to 24 GB
    – Applies to both baseline tenants and tenant extensions
  • Automatic update to 24 GB for all provisioned or procured tenants
  • A memory estimator will be released to support transparent planning of memory requirements
  • The soon to be released Self Monitoring app can be used to check data consumption and trends
  • Changes become effective January 21, 2026

 

What this means for tenant extensions

The SAP Cloud ALM tenant extension offers flexible scaling options. The included memory and outbound traffic entitlements can be used to increase the resources of your existing productive tenant, to provision additional tenants, or to combine both. Memory and outbound traffic are shared across the base tenant and any extension tenants. SAP recommends operating with a single productive SAP Cloud ALM tenant whenever possible.

With the purchase of one tenant extension, you are entitled from day one to a total of 48 GB of SAP HANA memory and 48 GB of outbound traffic per month. These entitlements can be consumed independently and do not require provisioning an additional tenant – you may use them entirely to scale your productive tenant.

If an additional tenant is needed, for example for testing or configuration validation, it can be provisioned and the available memory and outbound traffic are dynamically distributed across the productive and test tenants. When purchasing two tenant extensions, up to two additional tenants can be provisioned, with a total of 72 GB of memory and outbound traffic dynamically shared across up to three tenants. At no time is an additional tenant required to benefit from the extra entitlements provided by a tenant extension.

Call to Action

👉Check your current data consumption using Health Monitoring
👉Review your monitoring scope and enable additional use cases where needed
👉Watch for the upcoming sizing guide to plan future memory requirements confidently

We look forward to your feedback and discussions!

entry.title: Auto Packing with Nested Handling Units in Inbound Delivery – SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Automatic Packing with Nested Handling Units in Inbound Delivery – SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud

  • Nested Handling Units (HUs) mean packing one Handling Unit inside another Handling Unit.
  • For example, cartons packed into a pallet, where each carton and the pallet have their own HU number.

Step 1: Maintain Packaging Material Types. The menu path is shown in the screenshot below.

Note: I have created 2 Packaging Material types:

  • Pallet
  • Carton

Step 2: Define Material group for Packaging Materials

 

  • Created Packing Material groups for Pallet and Carton.

Step 3: Define Allowed Packaging Materials

  • Map the Packing Material Type with the Packing Material Group

  • Note - For Nested HUs, it is mandatory to cross-map Packing Material Types with Packing Material Groups.

This means:

  • Carton groups must allow pallet types, and
  • Pallet groups must allow carton types,
  • so that inner HUs can be packed into outer HUs without errors.

Step 4: Assign Number Range intervals to Packaging Material Type

  • Assign a number range to the created Packing Material Types for the respective plant and storage location.

Step 5: Created packing materials in MM01 using Material Type VERP and assign the relevant Packing Material Group and Pack. Material Type in the “Matl Grp Pack. Matls, Packing Material type” fields under the Basic Data view/Sales: General Plant data. Additionally, assign the appropriate HU Type and also created SFG Material.

In this scenario, two packing materials are created:

  • CARTONBOX with Packing Material Type CARTON
  • PALLET1 with Packing Material Type PALLET
  • 42 with SFG type.

 

Step 6:  Create Packing Instructions using T-Code: POP1

  • Please note that the Handling Unit (HU) number is generated only for the Load Carrier maintained in a Packaging Instruction.
  • As a result, to generate HUs for both cartons and pallets, each must be defined as a Load Carrier. Since a Packaging Instruction can contain only one Load Carrier, separate Packaging Instructions are required for cartons and pallets.
  • Based on this approach, the following Packaging Instructions have been created:

  • Created Packing Instruction “AutoPack”, added Components for Cotton Box.

  • Maintain check profile.

  • Check and save.

  • A separate Packaging Instruction is created for the pallet by adding the PALLET material as Item Category “P” and the AUTOPACK packaging instruction as Item Category “I”. Maintain the required quantities, then check and save.

Step 7: For automatic determination of the Packaging Instruction, create a condition record using T-code POF1.

  • Select “RCPT” standard for Inbound delivery.

  • Assign the SFG material and the ‘PALLET’ Packaging Instruction in the determination record.

Step 8:  Enable Auto Packing in Delivery Types

  • Selected Standard “EL” delivery type for Inbound delivery
  • Enabled “Automatic Packing” and save

The above are the configuration steps. The functional flow is explained below.

  • Created PO by selecting Confirmation key.

  • Create the inbound delivery, select the line item, and click ‘Auto Packing’. The system automatically packs the material.

In this scenario, Material 42 – SFG Material is maintained.

  • Each Carton Box is defined to carry 25 KG of SFG material.
  • Multiple Carton Boxes are then packed into a Pallet, where one pallet contains 4 carton boxes.
  • A Purchase Order is created for 100 KG of 42 SFG material.

During Inbound Delivery Auto Packing, the system performs the packing automatically as follows:

  • 100 KG of SFG material is packed into 4 Carton HUs (25 KG each).
  • These 4 Carton HUs are nested and packed into 1 Pallet HU.

This demonstrates Nested Handling Unit (HU) auto packing, where inner Carton HUs are packed into an outer Pallet HU, and each level is assigned its own HU number automatically by the system.

entry.title: SAP Ariba Category Management 2602 Release Highlights
entry.content:
Hello SAP Ariba Source to Contract Community, and welcome to this latest blog post on the exciting updates coming to SAP Ariba Category Management. This first quarter of 2026, SAP Ariba Category Management updates focus on turning strategy into action, strengthening risk and cost visibility, and making category managers’ day-to-day work simpler and more accountable. The changes are straightforward to adopt and deliver clear business value: faster decision cycles, better traceability, tighter governance, and better control of customizations.

1. Enhancements to External Factors Analysis Tool (ARBCATA-574)

The External Factors Analysis Tool now lets you create risk assessments directly from the External Factors Analysis page, attach supporting links or files, and link or create factors while working in the Risk Assessments page. Exported PDFs include assessment and attachment details, and terminology has been simplified to “Key Factors” across the Manage Configurations app and the Develop Strategy and Plan app.
The result - richer, context-aware records that reduce manual follow-up and make stakeholder reporting and audits far easier.

The above image shows a new button Create now available in the Risk Assessment section. This allows you to create a risk for the external factor as needed

The above image shows a new section Attachments now available in the page used to add attachments in the form of links or files as additional resources.

The above images shows a new button Create now available in the External Factors Analysis section allowing you to create an external factor for the risk as needed.

 

2. Ability to manage tasks on initiatives (CATMAN-466)
The Initiatives tool include a Tasks section where you can create, edit, delete, and update task status. Task owners can be given a “Can complete own tasks” permission and receive assignment notifications. Turning initiatives into assignable work increases accountability, improves progress visibility, and shortens the path from plan to delivery.

The above image shows a new section Tasks available in the Initiatives page, used to create, edit, and delete tasks associated with initiatives.

You can also update the task status by selecting Set as Started or Set as Completed buttons shown in above image

A new permission, Can complete own tasks, is now available in the Add Collaborators dialog, as shown in above image


3. Enhanced Cost Structure Analysis with Cost Models and Two-Level Cost Structure (ARBCATA-490)

With this feature, it is possible to define and assign cost models centrally and associate them with cost-structure documents. Cost charts now show two levels of cost components, exposing both top-level and secondary drivers so sourcing teams can compare scenarios and negotiate from a clearer view of supplier economics.

In above image you can see a new option, Cost Models, now available in the Strategy and Plan dropdown menu. Select Cost Models to create, edit, or delete cost models.

The Cost Models page is shown above. Use Create to add a new cost model, or select an existing one to edit, activate, inactivate, or delete it.

 

A new field, Cost Model, is now available on the Cost Structure page, shown above. You can use this field to associate cost structure documents with a cost model.

 

The Cost Structure page now displays a graph showing the two-level cost structure components, as seen above


4. Enhancements to Risk Assessments in SAP Ariba Category Management and Trend Monitoring (ARBCATA-513)
This feature introduces the following user interface enhancements for risk assessments in SAP Ariba Category Management. Changes include a standardized two-level risk structure that can be configured in the Manage Configurations , improved filtering, and a consolidated risk trend chart. These changes make risk comparisons consistent across assessments and give managers a fast, visual sense of how risks evolve over time.

A new Risk Categories section is now available (seen in above image) for every risk type on the Strategy and Plan  Risk Types page, allowing you to select a risk type and associate relevant risk categories with it.

The above image shows new filtering options available on the Risk Assessments page

A new risk score tag is displayed at the top of the screen for risk score analysis, as seen in above image

5. Enhancements to Manage Category Profile and Monitor Strategy Execution Pages (ARBCATA-568) 

Category profiles and Strategy and Plan Documents now appear in tables with extra filters, letting you find the right documents without extra clicks. The streamlined layout speeds discovery for managers and administrators and reduces navigation overhead.

The Manage Category Profile page now offers a comprehensive table listing category profiles with search filters, as seen above

 

In above image you can see the Monitor Strategy Execution page now offers a comprehensive table listing strategy and plan documents with search filters, allowing access to all documents irrespective of their status.

6. Ability to Use Custom Entities in Custom Tools of the Strategy and Plan Document (ARBCATA-539)
A new Extensibility Portal app is now available in the SAP Ariba Category Management launchpad which can be used to create custom entities and define custom fields for the entities. You cab then include the custom entities in custom tools, and personalize layouts with adapt UI functionality. These enhancements help capture organization-specific data for specific business purposes and reporting needs without heavy development work.

The new Custom Component option, seen in above image

 

Go ahead and review these items with your category leads and administrators to identify immediate wins - define or update cost models, clean up custom tools, and update playbooks to reflect task-based initiative management and richer risk reporting.

And, stay tuned for more enhancements and continue to leverage SAP Ariba Category Management to drive business success!

entry.title: SAP Cloud Integration – Getting started with Google Pub/Sub Adapter
entry.content:
Google Pub/Sub is a reliable messaging tool that lets your systems talk to each other securely using 'topics.' It’s great for sharing data in real-time across different cloud platforms. With the Google Pub/Sub adapter in SAP CPI, you can easily send or receive messages, making it much simpler to connect your SAP processes with Google Cloud 

The Google Pub/Sub Adapter is available in both sender and receiver modes to streamline message-based workflows and comes in two variants — REST and gRPC. 

Key Features 

  • Publish single messages (Basic) or multiple messages (Advanced) at once. 
  • Use gRPC for real-time performance or REST for polling at defined intervals. 
  • Google Pub/Sub accepts only Base64-encoded data, and the adapter can handle encoding automatically. 
  • Provides multiple post-processing options: Acknowledge after Successful Processing, Acknowledge Immediately, and Do not Acknowledge.  
  • Supports Authentication via OAuth2 service account authentication and Workload Identity Federation.  

Practical Use Case Walkthrough 
 
In this section, we will demonstrate how to send SalesOrder data to a topic using the Google Pub/Sub Receiver adapter and then read the message again with the Google Pub/Sub Sender adapter, using the REST protocol for messaging. 

Publish a Message using Google PubSub Receiver Adapter 

Prepare Payload in Content Modifier  
 
For the demonstration, we hardcode the SalesOrder data into the message body. In real time, you can dynamically store the payload from the source system. 

Configure the Google Pub/Sub Receiver Adapter 

Connection tab: 

Parameter  

Description  

Address  

Specify the hostname to connect Google Pub/Sub. 

Authentication Type  

Select the method for authentication to Google Pub/Sub. 

  • OAuth2 Service Account 
  • Workload Identity Federation  

OAuth2 Token URL  

Specify the OAuth2 Token URL which identifies as the authorization server for producing a JWT token internally.  

Client Email  

Specify Google Service Account Client Email. 

Private Key Alias  

Specify the Google Service Account Private Key for authentication.  

Scope  

Specify the scope of the connection to Google Pub/Sub service. 

Reuse Connection  

Enable the reuse of connection objects from the internal connection pool which in turn improves the network turnaround time for multiple communications to the same end point. 

Connection Timeout (in ms)  

Specify the maximum waiting time (in milliseconds) for the connection to be established with Google Pub/Sub service.  

Response Timeout (in ms)  

Specify the maximum waiting time (in milliseconds) for a response message to be received with Google Pub/Sub service.   

Publish Message using Google Pub/Sub Adapter 

Now let’s navigate to the Processing tab, select the Entity as Topic, and select the operation as Publish Message for the use case. 

Also, provide the project ID and topic ID created on the Google Pub/Sub server. 

Processing Tab: 

Parameter 

Description 

Entity  

Select the entity for message processing:  

  • Topics 
  • Subscriptions  

Operation  

Select the operation to be performed.  

  • Publish Message
  • List  

Project ID  

Specify the Google Pub/Sub project ID.  

Topic ID  

Specify the Topic ID created on Google Pub/Sub service 

Operation Type  

Select the type of operation  

  • Basic 
  • Advanced  

Encode Data  

Select the checkbox to encode data to Base64 

Ordering key  

Specify the ordering key for this message.   

Message Attributes  

Specify multiple message attributes as key value pairs. 

Once you run the iflow, you can see the message processed successfully. 

In addition, you can see that the Sales Order message was successfully published to the Google Pub/Sub service. 

Read a Message using Google Pub/Sub Sender Adapter 

The Google Pub/Sub Sender Adapter is available in gRPC and REST formats. For this demonstration, we're using the REST variant. 

Processing Tab: 

In the Google Pub/Sub Sender Adapter, provide the Subscription ID and Project ID from which the message will be read on the Google Pub/Sub Server.  

You can also select the post-processing action once the message has been polled from the Google Pub/Sub Server. 

Once the iflow is successfully deployed, we can check it in the monitoring page. In response, we can see the message body. 

Conclusion: 

The Google Pub/Sub adapter in SAP CPI brings integrations to life by allowing real-time, event-driven communication between SAP and Google Cloud. It enables CPI to easily publish and receive messages at scale, making integrations faster, more responsive, and loosely linked. The adapter's cloud-native design enables the creation of modern, durable integrations that can quickly change with business needs. 

Quick Links: 

  • For information about Google Pub/Sub Sender adapter configuration, see  SAP Help | Google Pub/Sub Sender Adapter.  
  • For information about Google Pub/Sub Receiver adapter configuration, see  SAP Help | Google Pub/Sub Receiver Adapter.  
  • For detailed information about the Google Pub/Sub adapter, see Google Pub/Sub Adapter Guide 

The next blog will take this further with an exciting new use case — so stay tuned for more insights and updates!

entry.title: UoM changed in Va02 not reflecting in MB51
entry.content:
Hi,

A sales order is created in VA01 with order quantity in bottles. After saving the order, the entry is showing in MB51.  Then the user goes to VA02 to change the unit from bottles to Cases. After saving the order when checking MB51, the new units (CS) and the converted quantity not showing in the list of MB51. 

When debugged, I could see that MSEG table is not hit for any updates during the process and I can see that MB51 fields are coming from MSEG.

I would like to understand if this is expected behavior or if there is anything I am missing. If I cannot see the changes in MB51, where should I check?

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: Mass upload for Custom Business Object in SAP Public Cloud
entry.content:
Introduction:

We can create a Custom business object using Key user extensibility in SAP Public cloud. We can also create a USER INTERFACE to maintain a database record.

Though we often have a requirement to do one time mass data upload in such CBO. One would have a hard time to do so with standard available options. I have tried out to cover this scenario in this blog post.

Problem Statement:

Custom Business Objects created via Key User Extensibility in SAP Public Cloud by default allows single record maintenance through the user interface, but do not support mass data uploads natively.

Solution:

This workaround involves enabling service generation for the CBO to expose it as an OData service, creating a custom communication scenario and arrangement, and using the service URL with Postman to post data entries individually or in bulk.

Here are the following steps:

  • Create a Custom Business object (CBO) Creating Custom Business Objects | SAP Help Portal
  • Make sure to check Service Generation, so the CBO can be called via OData and User Interface if you want to create database entry using a Screen manually.

     

  • Add required fields and business logic in the CBO
  • Publish it
  • Assign CBO to Custom Communication Scenario
  • Create Custom Communication Arrangement for Custom Communication Scenario created above
  • You will then find your Service URL for your CBO – Under Inbound Service section. Your CBO is now exposed as OData service.
  • We are now ready to use this Service URL in Postman

  • You can now put below Headers for your POST call



  • Test with a single entry. Put your data in JSON format under Request BODY (Choose option RAW)



  • Hit Send button and table record is created. That means you are all set to perform mass update.

  • Mass upload process:
    Prepare data in Excel, convert it to JSON array format, and use Postman’s Runner feature with the JSON file to iterate POST requests for each record. This approach circumvents the limitation of posting multiple records in a single request and allows successful mass loading of data into the CBO using a *.JSON file.

    Here are the following steps:

  • First create an excel with required data.
  • Now convert this file in JSON format file. One can also use available online tools for this purpose (as per your IT compliance).
  • Here is a sample for above excel data into JSON format. File name is data.JSON

     

  • Observe that it is in an array format, so everything will be within [ .. ]

Also, all rows should be entered using the same structure within {..} separated by Comma.

  • Now here is a catch, if you place multiple records in request body, then system will not allow you to do the same and throws an error.
  • To overcome this, we must consider below steps.

  • Put your variables to pick these values from JSON file. For that, you need to update your request body. An example below for our scenario.

 

  • Find out the Runner option in Postman. Most likely it’s on the top or bottom of your App.

     

 

  • Now choose your data.JSON file from your local machine.

     



  • A preview popup will be displayed with potential values. Choose option USE LOCALLY.

 

 

  • Now drag and Drop your Collection request, so that it will be placed one by one using your data. JSON file.

 

 

  • Ensure that only required request is selected from your collection. In our scenario, I am choosing POST request.

     

  • Now you’re ready to execute your Mass load request. Click on RUN MY COLLECTION button.

     

Request is processed successfully. Here is a snapshot of response body.

  • Finally, we can see the records in our CBO.

 

Final Remarks:

Mass data upload into Custom Business Objects in SAP Public Cloud is not supported out-of-the-box, but with the right combination of service generation, OData exposure, and Postman’s Runner feature, this limitation can be overcome. By converting your Excel data into JSON format and leveraging Postman collections, you can automate record creation and achieve a smooth bulk upload process.


This approach provides a practical workaround for one-time or recurring mass data loads, saving significant manual effort and ensuring consistency in your CBO entries. While it may not be as seamless as native integration tools, it empowers key users and developers to handle real-world scenarios efficiently without waiting for additional product features.


In short, with a bit of setup and the right tools, you can transform what seems like a limitation into a manageable process-making Custom Business Objects far more versatile in SAP Public Cloud.
